Fedspeak:

Fed's Dudley (voter) said 'strong case' for gradual hikes and that he is worried growth overheating is a risk, while he added the Fed may have to press harder on the breaks at some point. Dudley also said three Fed hikes in 2018 is not an unreasonable starting point and sees inflation rising to target in the medium term and unemployment falling under 4% this year. (Newswires)

Mexican Finance Minister said that NAFTA negotiations are advancing in an orderly manner. (Newswires)


EQUITIES

EQUITIES: SPX +0.7% at 2768, DJI +0.8  at 25574 , NDX +0.7 at 6708

Top sectors: Energy +2.0%, Cons. Disc. +1.6%, Industrials +1.3%
Bottom sectors: Utilities -0.4%, Cons. Stap -0.1%, Telecoms +0.1%

Major US bourses printed fresh record highs on Thursday. Energy stocks were lifted by crude prices surging towards three-year highs, with Brent clearing $70, while WTI climbed to $64. Airlines were also stronger following decent earnings from Delta.

There were a few equity market jitters after a batch of poor PPI data out of the US, hinting at lower inflationary pressures in the pipeline. However, equities were quick to shrug off the weakness.

Financials were little changed on the day ahead of tomorrow’s earnings from JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, BlackRock and PNC Financial Services. The Street looks for aggregated S&P 500 earnings growth of 12%, on average, with energy companies likely to drive gains, according to Reuters.


TREASURIES

US T-Note Futures settle +4 ticks higher at 123-04

US paper moved lower on decent enough volume. The Asia session was dominated by China-related headlines, with the SAFE playing down the Bloomberg sources piece that hit yesterday, regarding China’s purchases of US government debt. As you would expect this put a bid into Treasuries during the overnight session.

The space hovered around best levels heading in to the release of the latest ECB meeting minutes, which were deemed hawkish as a result of the following passage: “Looking ahead, the view was widely shared among members that the Governing Council’s communication would need to evolve gradually, without a change in sequencing, if the economy continued to expand and inflation converged further towards the Governing Council’s aim. The language pertaining to various dimensions of the monetary policy stance and forward guidance could be revisited early in the coming year.”

This allowed some concession heading in to today’s 30-year supply which stopped screens by 2.1bps, foreign buyers stepped in leaving the indirect takedown at the highest level on record, while the BTC was the highest since December 2014.


ASIA-PAC

Further to comments from SAFE, the Chinese foreign ministry have dismissed yesterday's reports on USTs as fake news. (Newswires)


EU/UK

UK PM May’s spokesperson said they have made it clear they will not pay the EU for access to financial services. (Newswires)

ECB Minutes: Forward guidance and the language surrounding their policy stance could be revisited in the early stages of this year. Communication would need to change but without changing sequencing. There was increased confidence that inflation pressures would take hold and short-term downward pressure on core inflation was temporary. (Newswires)

EU Industrial Production MM (Nov) 1.0% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 0.2%, Rev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
EU Industrial Production YY (Nov) 3.2% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 3.7%, Rev. 3.9%)

German Full Year GDP (2017) 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 1.9%)

The IFO Chief economist said that there is no end in sight for the German economic boom, and that growth will remain strong in 2018 & 2019. (Newswires)


FX

The FX space experienced another very whippy session, with the USD ultimately edging lower after the DXY traded above 92.50 in early European dealing.

Weaker than forecast US data undermined the greenback, after a relatively hawkish ECB meeting minutes release boosted the EUR, with the EURUSD cross settling around 1.2050 and EURGBP consolidating hovering around 0.8900

JPY continued to grind higher, with USDJPY hitting fresh lows in lieu of the solid US 30-year auction. Oil selling-off towards settlement also put pressure on USDJPY, with 111.00 in sight as we head into APAC trade.

Commodity FX drifted upwards on the back of crude gains, however, NAFTA headline risk kept the CAD subdued; the Loonie has been content with sideways trade

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA- Nat Gas, Change Bcf (w/e) -359B vs. Exp. -318B (Prev. -206B).

WTI futures settle 23 cents higher at $63.80 per barrel; Brent futures settle 6 cents higher at $69.26 per barrel.

Crude continued to push higher, helped by higher bond yields, a rumour of an explosion at the Escravos-Lagos gas pipeline in Nigeria and the softer USD. Brent briefly printed above USD 70.00/bbl before pulling back. Crude did come under selling pressure heading into settlement, with profit-taking being cited.

Natural Gas futures broke above USD 3.00 in early US trade, pushing to fresh highs as the weekly EIA storage data revealed a record drawdown, exceeding the estimated drawdown.

PREVIEW: Earnings Season Q4 2017
content:
Earnings season kicks off this week with some of the larger US financials reporting, including JPMorgan and Wells Fargo. For Q4, the S&P 500 is expected to see earnings grow by 11.8% Y/Y, a faster pace of growth than the last two quarters. The sectors leading the growth are expected to be Energy, Materials, Technology, and Financials, while the Telecoms sector is the only one forecast to provide negative earnings growth.

THINGS TO WATCH

As is always the case, the unofficial earnings season kick-off starts with the Financial sector which will be in focus after the recent Fed rate hikes and upcoming tax changes. A number of banks, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, have already said the impending tax changes will cause a hit in the short term, although in the long-term lower corporation tax should be beneficial.

The tax changes will make this reporting season “noisy” as companies are expected to report charges and other “special items” while also lifting expectations for 2018.

Companies with excessive overseas cash piles, particularly tech names, are expected to take large one-off charges as they had previously been able to defer US tax on offshore cash but will now have to pay the tax, albeit over the next 8 years.

On the other hand, those companies with deferred tax liabilities should book large one-off profits. The FT reports that AT&T could report a one-off gain of approx. USD 25bln.

The next question is what will happen to repatriated cash from offshore. Prudential Financial Chief Market Strategist said what they want to see and hear from companies is what they do with the cash, be that M&A, increasing capex or share buybacks and dividends. JPMorgan say that increasing investment may be better for the economy but would ultimately disappoint investors.

content: Another very whippy session with several swings in direction and sentiment, but the Usd ending on the back foot overall as the DXY slips back below 92.000 from highs just over 92.500 at one stage. Weaker than forecast US data (PPI and weekly jobless claims) undermined the Greenback independently, but the EUR was boosted by hawkish ECB minutes prior to that, with Eur/Usd up more than a full point from 1.1930 lows and then nudging further ahead to reach 1.2050+. Eur/Gbp back on the 0.8900 handle as Sterling lagged, albeit Cable reclaiming 1.3500+ status and almost 1.3550. The Kiwi and Aud extended recent gains vs their US peer with Nzd/Usd through 0.7230 and nearly testing psychological resistance at 0.7250 at the base of the next bullish upside chart area up to 0.7270. Aud/Usd revisited overnight peaks just below 0.7890, with stops just above the next big figure increasingly enticing. CAD not really bothered about a slightly sub-consensus Canadian new house price index and outperforming its US counterpart to trade at the bottom end of a 1.2590-25 range, with the Loonie underpinned by a sharp rally in oil prices and positive, albeit conditional comments from the Foreign Minister on NAFTA negotiations (prepared for any eventuality, but potential for talks to end well). JPY vs the Usd within a 111.90-30 range and ending close to the base where bids are seen ahead of 111.00.

PREVIEW: US Treasury will auction USD 12bln of 30-year bonds on 11 January at 1800 GMT/1300 ET
content:
THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: Excluding bills, the US will this week sell a total of USD 56bln in 3s, 10s and 30s this week (USD 24bln of 3s on Tuesday, USD 20bln in a 10s reopening on Wednesday, USD 12bln in a 30s reopening on Thursday). The sales will raise a net USD 15.5bln in new cash, given the USD 40.5bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, according to TD Securities.

30-YEAR AUCTION: Ahead The Treasury complex is being driven by news that Chinese officials have recommended a slowing or complete halt of its US Treasury purchases, saying that the attractiveness of US Treasuries are diminishing relative to other assets. The news has helped push long-end yields up by over 10bps in the week thus far.

Auction in the 30-year sector have improved, as of late. All of the previous three have stopped-through the 1pm WI yield, and over the last six, the average tail as been 0bps.

“Final demand has increased somewhat,” Barclays writes. “On a three-month moving average basis, foreign demand has increased 5ppts, which has only been partially offset by slightly lower demand from investment funds.”

The latest positioning data indicates that Primary Dealers have trimmed their long positions in the 11-years+ since the last auction cycle.

Writing before news from china, analysts at Societe Generale hold a small positive bias going into the auction on the back of continuing demand for the long-end of the curve. “From an RV perspective, the current 30y is cheap on asset swap versus the old 30s compared with the previous two auctions, whereas the 5s30s curve has flattened by around 8bp since the last auction.”

The bank did believe that concession would be required, given that the sector appeared rich given that the 5s30s curve continues to flatten towards the lowest levels since 2007

30-YEAR PREVIOUS AUCTION HISTORY:
- High-yield: 2.804% (vs six auction average of 2.837%)
- Tail: -0.3bps (stops-through) (vs six auction average of 0.0bps)
- Bid-to-cover: 2.48x (vs six auction average of 2.35x)
- Dealers: 29.1% (vs six auction average of 30.3%)
- Directs: 9.0% (vs six auction average of 7.4%)
- Indirects: 61.9% (vs six auction average of 62.3%)

EUREX DEBT FUTURES: lower and flatter post-ECB minutes
content: No real shock to see Eurozone bonds back off on the hawkish vibes from the December ECB policy meeting via minutes revealing and reiterating that forward guidance may warrant an update early this year (March meeting seems most convenient coming with new Staff forecasts). Bunds down to 160.83 (-24 ticks, and just below yesterday’s Chinese-induced Eurex base), but not tumbling as far/fast as Bobls and Schatz as the curve flattens. 10 year yield almost up to 0.5%, as the ECB acknowledges that policy is still in emergency mode (despite the QE downsize) even though the economic developments are favourable. Note, the 5 year German benchmark has declined to fresh contract lows (131.33), while Eur/Usd has now reclaimed the 1.2000 marker. For Bunds, 160.76 now looks vulnerable.

PREVIEW: ECB December Meeting Minutes due at 1230GMT/0630CST
content: As a recap, last month saw the bank reiterate guidance that it expects rates to remain at current levels for an extended period of time and well past the horizon of net asset purchases. Furthermore, despite the Bank being relatively upbeat on the Eurozone’s growth prospects (large upgrade to 2018 growth projections), Draghi quashed market expectations over the potential end-date for the ECB’s QE programme by stating that the matter was not discussed at the meeting. However, this was then followed by ECB Sources suggesting that a minority of ECB Rate Setters wanted to signal guidance may change if inflation keeps accelerating, hawks were easily outnumbered and the debate was not heated. Therefore, any guidance on the scope of the discussions and the split of views will be of interest to the market going forward, particularly in the context of recent comments from Mersch who warned against too slow an exit from monetary policy and Coeure who sees “a reasonable chance” the ECB's PSPP will not be extended again when it expires in September. HSBC are also looking out for details on any debate surrounding the split between public and corporate bond purchases from January 2018.

subject: IFO Chief economist said there is no end in sight for German economic boom,and growth remain strong in 2018 and 2019
Barclays on the BoJ
content:
We have partially revised our outlook for Japanese monetary policy. We still expect the BoJ to take its first step toward normalization in Q3 18, but now believe that will involve a shortening of the sector targeted for yield control (to the 5y from the 10y sector) versus our previous forecast for a hike in the targeted level of 10y yields.

In terms of steepening the yield curve (optimizing its shape), there may be no major difference between shortening the sector targeted for yield controls and continuing to target the 10y sector but at higher yields. However, the former might be preferred if the BoJ eventually aims to converge YCC toward more conventional monetary policy focused on short-term policy rates.

Normalizing monetary policy through a revision to YCC when realized CPI inflation is undershooting targeted inflation at around 1% even in H2 18 might be justified by the following: 1) a stepwise adjustment in interest rates based on a Taylor rule-type policy reaction function for managing YCC; 2) a tilting of the trade-off between the benefits of prolonged monetary easing (eg, higher inflation expectations, accommodative financial conditions) and the side-effects (eg, decline in fiscal discipline, deterioration in earnings of financial institutions) toward the latter, as evident from the extensive discussion on the reversal rate since last year; and 3) tailwinds to normalization from the external environment, eg, the government’s anticipated declaration of an end to deflation around mid2018, the prospect of sustained rate hiking by the Fed. At the same time, we expect the BoJ to retain its negative interest rate policy through 2018, unwinding NIRP (restoring the zero interest rate policy, ZIRP) in Q1 19 rather than in Q4 18, as we previously forecast.

In terms of quantitative easing (QE) – the other major component of the current monetary policy program – we expect the BoJ to retain its current guideline for the supply of base money through JGB purchases (JPY80trn/year), while continuing to allow actual buying to decrease (stealth tapering) in accordance with JGB supply and demand. Even under our new forecasts, we continue to expect the focus of monetary policy to shift from “quantity” to “rates” and from the long-term to the short-term sector under YCC.

subject: DAILY US OPENING NEWS: China SAFE said that report on China mulling reduction in US Treasury purchases may cite a wrong source or be fake news
content:
• European equities trade relatively directionless with UK retail names underperforming following week trading updates
  • The Dollar Index is back within striking distance of the 92.500 level and firmer vs all G10 rivals bar its antipodean counterparts
  • Highlights include ECB minutes, US PPI, Fed’s Dudley and supply from the US

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly lower amid a dampened global risk tone, which was triggered by China concerns after officials were said to see US Treasuries as less attractive and recommended either cutting back or halting purchases altogether. This was viewed by some as an implicit threat by the world’s largest foreign holder of USTs against trade measures by the US, although China’s SAFE later suggested that the report may have cited a wrong source or could be fake news. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) were both subdued with broad-based weakness across nearly all sectors in Australia, while Japanese stocks remained at the whim of the recent JPY strength. Chinese markets also conformed to the sombre picture with both Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.1%) initially cautious as the PBoC’s liquidity efforts continued to be on the light-side. Finally, 10yr JGBs found some reprieve from this week’s selling on mild short-covering and after the BoJ’s Rinban announcement in which purchases in 1yr-10yr maturities were maintained at a respectable amount of nearly JPY 1tln.

China SAFE said that report on China mulling reduction in US Treasury purchases may cite a wrong source or be fake news. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.5147 (Prev. 6.5207)
 

GLOBAL

Mexico will leave NAFTA negotiation if President Trump triggers 6-month process to withdraw from the deal, according to sources. (Newswires)

US VP Pence said in an interview that they will get spending bill passed before the funding deadline. However, there were also later reports that Leading Republicans are said to consider not passing a 'GOP' budget this year, amid concerns it may not pass Senate. (Politico)


EQUITIES

European equities trade relatively directionless (Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%) once again as European-specific newsflow remains on the light side. In terms of sector specifics, telecom and consumer discretionary names underperform, whislt stock specific movers include Tesco (-4.4%) and Marks & Spencers (-5%) who are at the foot of the FSTE 100 following disappointing trading updates. Elsewhere, Fiat Chrysler shares are underperforming in the FTSE MIB on NAFTA concerns.

FX

The Dollar Index is back within striking distance of the 92.500 level and firmer vs all G10 rivals bar its antipodean counterparts, as Chinese reports about curtailing US debt purchases are dismissed as false by SAFE and the Foreign Ministry. However, fresh NAFTA jitters are also underpinning the Greenback to the detriment of the Cad and Mxn. Usd/Cad has bounced further from last Friday’s divergent US/Canadian jobs data lows (1.2355) towards the 1.2593 100 DMA and offers around the 1.2600 level. BoC rate hike odds have lengthened dramatically in response to concerns that the trade talks could break down, while Usd/Mxn has spiked to 19.3000+ for the same reasons. Usd/Chf is back up near 0.9800 vs yesterday’s lows below 0.9750, and Usd/Jpy over 111.50 and through the 200 DMA at 111.72 and 111.85 supply to a high just shy of 111.90 at one stage, eyeing 112.00 offers/psychological resistance, before a 112.08 Fib and the 112.26 100 DMA. 111.40-35 provides support on the downside. Cable has retreated below 1.3500 and through 1.3480 stops (just), but could be drawn towards a 600+ mn option expiry at the figure, with bids seen at 1.3425. Eur/Usd has reversed towards recent low 1.1900 area lows vs Wednesday’s 1.2000+ high and may also be influenced by expiry interest given a big (2 bn) 1.1950 strike that runs off tomorrow. On that note, a Eur/Sek 9.8000 option in the same size could entice given that the strike is close to the current 9.7800 spot price. As noted, the Aud and Nzd are bucking the weaker vs Greenback trend, with Aud/Usd through 0.7860-65 stops and 0.7870 macro offers on the way to a 0.7885 overnight high in wake of much stronger than expected Aussie retail sales data. 0.7900+ stops lie ahead, as the Aud/Nzd cross reclaims 1.0900 and the Kiwi stalls just above 0.7200 vs the Usd.


FIXED INCOME

The turnaround from bear market territory to debt friendly if not bullish sentiment appears to have been confirmed by decent investor demand for sovereign issuance, and of course China’s apparent rejection of anti-US Treasury holdings headlines yesterday. Considerable concessions in advance of the auctions must be taken into consideration, but Italian BTPs have nudged new intraday peaks in wake of the results, not to mention the scramble for Wednesday’s 20 year syndication. Bunds, Gilts and USTs all holding the bulk of their recovery gains, but the last leg of this week’s US refunding still to come and the long bond perhaps not as attractive below 2.90% as it was when heading towards 2.95%. On the data front, US weekly jobless claims and PPI also on the agenda, as crude prices continue to rally and keep bond vigilantes on their toes.

COMMODITIES

Price action in WTI and Brent crude had been somewhat uneventful overnight, however prices broke above yesterday’s highs during European trade amid no fresh fundamental catalysts before extending gains after WTI tripped stops above USD 64.00bbl. In metals markets, precious metals have seen very little in the way of price action. Elsewhere, nickel hit a 2-month high in Chinese trade following tight stocks whilst copper saw mild gains as prices tested USD 2.50/lb to the upside.

UAE Energy Minister says there is a commitment to continue OPEC deal for a full year and that oil market is still rebalancing, expects to achieve full balanced oil market this year

Euro Stoxx 50 up slightly by 0.05% while large swings have been seen in the likes of Tesco’s and Pandora after there soft earnings update. Elsewhere, Fiat Chrysler shares are underperforming in the FTSE MIB on NAFTA concerns.

FX

Fixed Income
Core debt extending to the upside after a brief period of consolidation and pull-back, with trading volumes picking up, albeit nowhere near as heavy as they were on the sell-side when China’s false US Treasury claims sparked a near rout. Nevertheless, decent clips  have been bought in 10 year US T-note futures in a relatively short space of time, while Bunds and Gilts climbed to fresh Eurex and Liffe session highs at 161.54 and 124.50 (+47 and +38 ticks), the former achieving a 50% retrace of this week’s move, at 161.48, and stopping just short of the 161.56-60 zone that could trip stops before 161.76. For the 10 year UK benchmark, 124.56, 124.73 and 124.95 form the next upside tech objectives, but as noted looming supply may deter bulls.

Commodities
Price action in WTI and Brent crude had been somewhat uneventful overnight, however prices have recently broken out of its tight range, to trade at intra-day highs, with the latter breaking yesterday’s high of USD 69.37/bbl.

Bunds: decent rebound on Chinese US Treasury denial
content: The 10 year German benchmark gapped up ¼ point-plus off the open and is looking to build on healthy recovery gains as China’s Foreign Ministry follows SAFE with a firm denial of Wednesday’s reports suggesting foreign bond portfolio diversification away from US Treasuries. Core debt also encouraged by a stellar 10 year auction as yields approaching 2.6% drew strong demand, and perhaps poignantly from indirect bidders that incorporate overseas buyers. The Eurex high so far is 161.44 vs yesterday’s 161.07 close and the 161.91 intraday low, with the yield backing off from the 0.5% area (on the 2027 maturity) vs 0.54% for the new 2028 maturity when issued. Tech-wise, 161.56-60 represents the next upside chart resistance area, but Bunds may be reluctant to extend that far ahead of ECB minutes, which could highlight more hawkish views about setting an end date for QE (as per the tone of recent commentary from several Board members). Indeed, initial/early momentum is already stalling amidst a pull-back to 161.31, and on the downside 161.20 is nearest support.

subject: DAILY BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: Supply today comes from Italy, UK and US
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: Italian EUR 2.5-3bln 0.2% 2020 and 1.45% 2024 Bond Auction

Outright concession supports auctions, worth 20bp for 10-year BTPs. Longer dated paper has sold off more aggressively amid a bear steepening. Good concession for BTPs against Bonos.. Concession for longer dated BTPs also in against core markets and swaps, however a good concession was no help for weak 2/28 Bund auction yesterday. Competing supply an issue, but big redemptions coming to provide support.

Historical Data

0.2% Oct’2020 Prev. b/c 1.794 and average yield -0.02%

1.45% Nov’2024 Prev. b/c 1.438 and average yield 1.21%

Bids are submitted by 1000GMT and results are published shortly after.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: UK GBP 2.25bln 1.75% 2037 Gilt Auction

History indicates that results have always been a little on the soft side for the line. Looking at the curve, the line has lost around 13bp since the last tap, so there is little in the way of any natural concession in place. 10s/20s also offers little incentive with the curve around 6bp flatter than the October tap at 52.5bp.

As ever though with relatively new Gilts, the issue sits at an inherently cheap kink on the curve, trading around 6bp cheap on the mismatched fly between the 4Q36s and the 4T38s, which should also help the cause. So all in all, considering that longer dated sales historically attract institutional demand, little drama is in prospect although risks must be skewed towards softer results.

Historical Data

1.75% Sep’2037 Prev. b/c 1.85, average yield 1.941% and a tail of 0.4bps

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are published shortly after.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: US Treasury will sell USD 12bln of 30-year bonds

US Treasury will auction USD 12bln of 30-year bonds on 11 January at 1800 GMT/1300 ET

THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: Excluding bills, the US will this week sell a total of USD 56bln in 3s, 10s and 30s this week (USD 24bln of 3s on Tuesday, USD 20bln in a 10s reopening on Wednesday, USD 12bln in a 30s reopening on Thursday). The sales will raise a net USD 15.5bln in new cash, given the USD 40.5bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, according to TD Securities.

30-YEAR AUCTION: Ahead The Treasury complex is being driven by news that Chinese officials have recommended a slowing or complete halt of its US Treasury purchases, saying that the attractiveness of US Treasuries are diminishing relative to other assets. The news has helped push long-end yields up by over 10bps in the week thus far.

Auction in the 30-year sector have improved, as of late. All of the previous three have stopped-through the 1pm WI yield, and over the last six, the average tail as been 0bps.

“Final demand has increased somewhat,” Barclays writes. “On a three-month moving average basis, foreign demand has increased 5ppts, which has only been partially offset by slightly lower demand from investment funds.”

The latest positioning data indicates that Primary Dealers have trimmed their long positions in the 11-years+ since the last auction cycle.

Writing before news from china, analysts at Societe Generale hold a small positive bias going into the auction on the back of continuing demand for the long-end of the curve. “From an RV perspective, the current 30y is cheap on asset swap versus the old 30s compared with the previous two auctions, whereas the 5s30s curve has flattened by around 8bp since the last auction.”

The bank did believe that concession would be required, given that the sector appeared rich given that the 5s30s curve continues to flatten towards the lowest levels since 2007

30-YEAR PREVIOUS AUCTION HISTORY:
- High-yield: 2.804% (vs six auction average of 2.837%)
- Tail: -0.3bps (stops-through) (vs six auction average of 0.0bps)
- Bid-to-cover: 2.48x (vs six auction average of 2.35x)
- Dealers: 29.1% (vs six auction average of 30.3%)
- Directs: 9.0% (vs six auction average of 7.4%)
- Indirects: 61.9% (vs six auction average of62.3%)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets were mostly lower amid a dampened global risk tone. In FX, AUD outperformed its major peers after better than expected Retail Sales data
content:
• Asian equity markets were mostly lower amid a dampened global risk tone. In FX, AUD outperformed its major peers after better than expected Retail Sales data
  • China SAFE said that report on China mulling reduction in US Treasury purchases may cite a wrong source or be fake news.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB minutes, US PPI, Fed’s Dudley and supply from the UK and US

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly lower amid a dampened global risk tone, which was triggered by China concerns after officials were said to see US Treasuries as less attractive and recommended either cutting back or halting purchases altogether. This was viewed by some as an implicit threat by the world’s largest foreign holder of USTs against trade measures by the US, although China’s SAFE later suggested that the report may have cited a wrong source or could be fake news. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were both subdued with broad-based weakness across nearly all sectors in Australia, while Japanese stocks remained at the whim of the recent JPY strength. Chinese markets also conformed to the sombre picture with both Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (Unch.) cautious as the PBoC’s liquidity efforts continued to be on the light-side. Finally, 10yr JGBs found some reprieve from this week’s selling on mild short-covering and after the BoJ’s Rinban announcement in which purchases in 1yr-10yr maturities were maintained at a respectable amount of nearly JPY 1tln.

China SAFE said that report on China mulling reduction in US Treasury purchases may cite a wrong source or be fake news. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.5147 (Prev. 6.5207)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond said the UK goal for Brexit will be affected by EU approach and that the EU 27 need to spell out what they want after Brexit and states ‘It takes two to Tango’ regarding Brexit talks. Hammond also refused to rule out making substantial payments to the EU after Brexit in order to secure market access for British-based financial service firms. (Telegraph)

British financial firms will be allowed privileged access to European Union markets in return for payments to Brussels under plans being considered by countries including Germany. (Times) Furthermore, The UK PM May is set to meet with business leaders from the UK's financial services industry as the government attempts to secure a Brexit deal that will include the sector. (BBC)

ECB’s Villeroy said interest rates are currently very low and he raised Q4 growth estimate to 0.6% Q/Q from 0.5% previously. Furthermore, he also raised FY17 French growth estimate to 1.9%. (Prev. 1.8%). (Newswires)

FX

AUD outperformed its major peers after better than expected Retail Sales data pushed AUD/NZD back above the 1.0900 handle and saw EUR/AUD slip below 1.5200. Elsewhere, USD/JPY nursed some of the recent losses from this week’s flows into JPY and China’s speculated US Treasury sabre-rattling, as the greenback found late support after China’s government effectively denied it was considering lowering Treasuries purchases. NAFTA-related currencies were also in focus with CAD initially pressured on fears the US would pull out of NAFTA which the White House denied, while MXN weakened in sympathy and after reports Mexico will leave negotiations if President Trump triggers a 6-month process to withdraw from the deal.

Australian Retail Sales MM (Nov) 1.2% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)

Canada was said to be increasingly convinced the US will pull out of NAFTA, according to reports citing government sources. However, a White House official later stated that there was no change in US President Trump's position on NAFTA, while there were also reports that Mexico will leave NAFTA negotiations if President Trump triggers the 6-month process to withdraw from the deal. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodity trade was uneventful in which WTI crude futures stuck to the sideways performance seen despite yesterday’s slightly larger than expected DoE crude draw, as this was significantly less than the surprise seen in APIs and counterbalanced by a 3% drop in US output. Elsewhere, gold was flat and failed to benefit from mild gains in the greenback, while copper saw mild gains as prices tested USD 2.50/lb to the upside.

UAE Energy Minister said there is a commitment to continue OPEC deal for a full year and that the oil market is still rebalancing. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

South Korean President Moon is reportedly willing to hold a summit with North Korean Leader Kim. (Newswires)

US

Treasuries were hit in pre-market trade after news that officials in China – the largest foreign owner of US Treasuries – have recommended that the country slow or even stop purchases of US government bonds on the notion that they are becoming less attractive relative to other bonds. The immediate reaction was a sell-off in US debt, with 10-year yields within spitting distance of 2.60%, and 2s once again setting their crosshairs on 2.00%, while the USD also eased. However, losses were pared back, helped by a solid 10-year auction which stopped-through by 0.5bps on strong cover, while indirect bidders (one proxy for foreign demand) taking 71.5% of the issue. Furthermore, Treasuries had pared back the losses post-settlement and was underpinned in overnight trade after China cast doubt on the validity of the initial Treasury-related reports. 

US VP Pence said in an interview that they will get spending bill passed before the funding deadline. However, there were also later reports that Leading Republicans are said to consider not passing a 'GOP' budget this year, amid concerns it may not pass Senate. (Politico)
